title: The digital design industry is changing

data.content: It took just two months, but now it’s time to adjust to the new, much faster reality.
The pandemic came unexpectedly.
The IT people felt safe initially (and yes, that includes UX designers — we’re the IT crowd too), but after a while it started to negatively affect everyone.
Companies are cutting funding, budgets are dropping and the building processes are turning more and more agile. Some can even call them recklessly agile.
I’ve been watching the changes in the industry closely for the last two months and based on LinkedIn posts, tweets and our own experience with incoming leads I came to a couple of conclusions.
The jobs
Out of just my feeds I noticed 29 UXers lose their jobs. 12 Front-end developers were also unlucky. No back-end developers popped out in my feed, so I guess a lot of them are safe.
But what’s surprising UI designers are doing quite good. I have only seen 2 “purely UI” people getting fired (still, talking about just my feed).

Some of the above UX people were UX/UI, but I quickly went through their portfolios to check out their skills, and most of them were really just UX designers with some UI knowledge. Nevertheless I tried to share each and every one of those posts further to help out, but that’s not my point here.

People are buying with their eyes, so especially now it may be easier to convince a customer with a dribbble-worthy set of shots in the portfolio, than a set of personas, some gray tables and diagrams.
Maybe some things can happen automatically?
AI is already simplifying and shortening some of those processes as we speak.
Maybe this is a good time to polish some UI skills a bit, and have a more eye-catching Resumé?
After all, all those processes can still (and should) be there, but start with a nice high-fidelity design on the first page — present the outcome and then show how you got there.
Generalists in the industry are going to be the ones in demand, especially as UI isn’t really as hard to learn as the whole UX process.
If you already got personas, card sorting, empathy maps and all the research methods nailed, then move those rectangles around a little bit and make them beautiful :)
https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/1*n9jnLiItdXR7hSU8tyF-Ag.png
The landscape

Even though I haven’t seen that many UI designers getting fired, I noticed something even more unexpected — there’s a lot less quality Dribbble shots being added. We were able to get to Popular for a few days in a row, which was previously very difficult to achieve.
So if they’re still working, I have no idea why the portfolio-building activity decreased.
But it did.
Some of the accounts I followed closely also post a lot less now, than they used to, even with all the team members still there.
Maybe people are a bit less motivated to work from home? I wrote a story about how I think working from home can have some negative consequences a while ago.
The leads
The fact that the average budgets decreased (about 20–30%) was to be expected. Only essential products are being built right now. Or the “sure” ones.

But we also noticed another thing — nearly 90% of the coming leads are sending their own wireframes now. They already have a product vision defined. About half of them have done some basic research themselves too.
Quite often we get full lo-fi prototypes in Figma, which has also hugely gained on popularity among our leads and customers.
What those customers want is guidance, an audit of what they already have and then yes … the UI and the coding.

Nobody asked us for personas or even flow-diagrams in those two months. People want to get straight to the point. When faced with a proposal of a longer process they often cite lower budgets and much faster execution times.
They want to get the product to market ASAP and test it on people.

This is why Speed Designing is also gaining popularity. The “dumbing down” of the process comes naturally. All the non-essential parts of it (that were often used to make the customer pay more) are now frowned upon from the start.
Results, Results, Results
Luckily the trend is still very strong on Research — both prototype testing and MVP response analysis. Click-tracking (hotjar etc.) became even more popular for web projects in the last two months.
Nearly all the clients already know about that research method and they want to implement it right away.
Faster to market

The general shift right now is to be a lot faster. And I believe this is going to continue in that direction. There won’t be a lot of time for “processes”. They need to be more flexible and simply faster from now on.
Hopefully the lockdowns and the entire global crisis will be over soon and we can come back to sort-of-how-it-was-before.
And maybe being faster is not that bad actually. It allows you to “see” what you’re building a lot faster as well, and that brings in a sense of accomplishment and joy.
Releasing products to market is a lot of fun.
Let’s make them great!
